I recently had lunch at Love & Light and it was fantastic! The meal was both delicious and healthy, with a refreshing smoothie that left me feeling energized. Choosing from their diverse menu was tough, but every option was tempting. I loved the Buddha bowl with salmon. Portion was generous, allowing me to enjoy leftovers the next day. I highly recommend this spot to anyone in the neighborhood looking for great healthy food and a welcoming atmosphere! Can't wait to go back! :)

The owner herself made sure the process of planning was a piece of cake and stress free which was definitely a plus for me. We all felt super comfortable and like we were at home. The food and drinks were 100% amazing! No complaints at all I would definitely choose this place for any of my other events!

One of the best restaurants/bars in Charlotte. Everything on the menu is good and a great selection of beers on draft. The wings, burger and fish and chips are some of the best I've had anywhere, and the vegetarian options on the menu are all exceptional. Great service too!
The food is excellent

If I get back to New Orleans, this will be my first choice of restaurant for lunch for dinner. They have a separate vegan menu with a great selection, and it was tough to decide what to order. My husband, sister, brother-in-law, and I were all thrilled with what we had and that we discovered this place. (Thank you Happy Cow!) (We all had the tofu satay; I had the Green Curry Tofu; hubby had the Khao Soi Tofu soup; sis had the Pumpkin Curry Tofu; brother-in-law had the spicy fried eggplant. Everything was delicious. I was told they do not use habenaro peppers, the peppers that make food hot pepper hot    . It is used to infuse flavor into Jamaican dishes but removed before it bursts into the dish. Or if it is used, they chop it and remove seeds where most of the heat lies dependent upon how ripe the pepper is. Or it can be leftbin the dish to burst for both the heat and flavor. However, not everyone can stand that Scoville scale of a hot pepper in their food. I appreciate that this establishment does not use pepper in their food.  It burns my stomach and other things. Though I was told at another restaurant, Jamaican food is "supposed to be hot  🥵", okay. But not everyone can eat peppery food. I am glad I can come here for Jamaican food that is not full of pepper.

We originally went as I was looking for a brunch restaurant that could accommodate my dad (he’s in a wheelchair/service dog), and we were also looking for something that prioritizes their food quality. Look, I like NOLA but I was tired of the standard, touristy, overpriced options. The pancakes in the Google listing + ability to make a reservation made the choice easy for us.

When we arrived we were greeted by the co-owner and immediately felt welcomed. It was an awesome surprise to also find that they offered delicious coffee options and we promptly ordered. We ordered an array of coffee (honey cinnamon latte, honey lavender latte, and iced vanilla bean logged - all delicious!) and for food the Lemon Ricotta pancakes, BLT, and Hot Chicken & Honey Biscuit. The pancakes are INCREDIBLE. My mother - who LOVES pancakes - was obsessed with them. The BLT was great and the hot chicken was so-so, but was made up by the delicious potatoes served as a side.

Upon leaving we immediately planned another day to come for breakfast for more pancakes. Upon our second visit we got more pancakes (the lemon + the Pigs in a Blanket), coffees, and the GM Plate. We were all satisfied and became curious on how they created the most perfect pancakes recipe. I’m not kidding - I hate pancakes and will now dream of them.

If you’re considering this place just do yourself a favor and go. Sure, the more “popular” choice is on the corner of the same strip, but it doesn’t compare to this place. Truly. The service, the atmosphere, and the menu are fantastic. Amazing!!

P.S. they have doughnuts/pastries and house-made ice cream as well. We never ordered them, but they all looked fantastic and had great flavor combos.

I found myself craving chicken that was both tasty and affordable before I take off for my New York City adventure tomorrow. A couple of months back, I was suggested to check out Hubee D’s in Meyers Park. I'm all about supporting local spots, so I decided to check it out. Walking in, I was warmly greeted by a very friendly gentleman at the counter—who turned out to be Mark, the owner. We got chatting, and he shared that he's originally from Jersey and boldly claims his chicken could rival any in town. I admire his confidence and passion for his food! Mark, with his rich background in the restaurant industry, dreams of opening a northern-style deli/luncheonette/breakfast spot in the future.

Since this was my first visit, Mark suggested trying something from their menu of scratch-made chicken entrees, including tenders, nuggets, sandwiches, wings, salads, and wraps.

With so much to choose from, I settled on a fried chicken sandwich with pickles and their signature zesty Hubee Sauce—reminiscent of Zaxby's Chicken Sauce—alongside a serving of well-seasoned matchstick French fries and creamy mac & cheese with a white cheddar sauce. Everything was made to order, arriving hot and fresh. When comparing Hubee D’s fried chicken sandwich to that famous chain that's closed on Sundays, Hubee D’s takes the crown. The chicken was perfectly breaded and fried—juicy and crispy. The Hubee sauce added just the right touch without being overpowering, and the bun was perfectly toasted, with the pickles providing a refreshing contrast.

While I usually lean towards baked mac & cheese, Hubee D’s saucy, creamy version was a delightful surprise.  So, if saucy mac & cheese is your thing, don't miss out on this one.
If you've driven past this local gem without stopping, make sure to bring the family next time. There’s something for everyone to enjoy! I'm already looking forward to my next visit to Hubee D’s!

P.S. Sorry for the half-eaten meal photo. I got caught up chatting with Mark and didn't want my food to cool down.

My wife and I had a terrible experience with this establishment. There were warning signs early that we ignored, so ultimately we could have avoided our lackluster dining experience.

We waited roughly 5 minutes for our server to greet us, placed a drink order along with an appetizer order. The server brought our waters and said our drinks would be out shortly. We started hearing the kitchen yelling for service for several minutes, the wait staff were elsewhere at this point, and then we started seeing the kitchen staff attempting to bring out the orders themselves. They were obviously confused as the whole each item was supposed to go to, but they were making an attempt. Kudos to the back of house for making an effort. They did make some negative comments about their coworkers as they were returning to the kitchen, we were sat by the kitchen so got to be the audience.

We received our appetizer after a few minutes of it being passed around from person to person before finally making it's way to our server.
We waited 10 minutes for our drinks to finally make it to our table, not promising for such a large business that wasn't busy. We had ordered the crab cake appetizer, it was very small, good flavor and quite a lot of crab for what looks like a 3 ounce cake. I would have been a little happier for either a little more or little less expensive ($26), this is obviously in the heart of the tourist trap but this was egregious even with that in mind. My entree was delivered within minutes of the drinks and appetizer. I had ordered the Blue Bayou shrimp Poboy, I was surprised by how much shrimp was on the sandwich especially after how small the appetizer was. My food sat on the table untouched for nearly 10 minutes before our server came to check on us, finding my wife's entree had never been delivered. She went back to the kitchen to check, came back out to apologize and said that the missing entree would be delivered shortly. We waited another 15 minutes for my wife's shrimp and grits entree, my food was now cold and we began eating our dinner.
The Poboy was not bad, even for being cold, it lacked some of the bold flavor you would expect for a Creole BBQ shrimp poboy but was more than edible. The side of fries were very good, large portions of shrimp and fries.
My wife said the shrimp and grits were okay, not as good as the same dish from the Ruby Slipper I had ordered for breakfast on the same day for significantly less money. But she did enjoy the dish well enough.

The server did offer to comp a glass of wine to make amends for the poor timing of the service, we declined and finished our meal. We found the service at this restaurant to be seriously lacking compared to the other establishments we visited during our visit to the city. The prices were on par with higher end establishments, but it falls short of the competition in my experience. We didn't walk in with any expectations, but we left disappointed with the overall experience.  We would not return or recommend this restaurant. There are too many great places to enjoy good food and drink in this city, avoid this lackluster tourist trap.

**Also of note - this restaurant charges an additional 3% on card payments, and they're a cashless business. So expect all prices to be an additional 3%***

Today, we were incredibly fortunate to visit a unique restaurant, Monocle, located on Capitol Hill. We initially chose it due to its proximity to our hotel, but it turned out to be a true "Washingtonian gem." Opened in 1960, this restaurant has been operated by the same family ever since. The menu is concise, which we believe highlights the culinary excellence presented in merely five dishes. We were in search of "authentic American steaks from real American beef from real American cows." What we received far exceeded our expectations. Both steaks we ordered were exquisitely prepared to perfection. We both agreed that these were the best steaks we've ever had the pleasure of eating in our lives. #Masterpiece

As if the meal itself wasn't enough, our server, Marinos Apostolopoulos, provided us with a genuine journey through the history of this establishment. We are deeply grateful!

Given its location near the Capitol, the restaurant has been visited by at least half of American politicians over the last 60 years, including Presidents Nixon, Kennedy, Bush, and Clinton. Celebrities like Robert De Niro and Al Pacino, among other incredible individuals, have also frequented this place. The number of VIPs and their dedications displayed in their own photos hanging on every wall is truly astonishing.

One of the servers celebrated his 50th work anniversary here two months ago with a surprise party for 250 people, an event that was featured on the front page of the Washington Post, which we had the opportunity to read.

The place is beautiful, with incredibly friendly service and excellent food. The wonderful experiences we had will stay with us forever. It's worth traveling for moments like these.
